content:
I think I had a "profound revelation" about issues in https://github.com/rust-analyzer/rust-analyzer/issues/10593#issuecomment-947537009.

So, I am wondering... Should we introduce explicit concept of "report" and "work item"? Ie, I imagine we can:

  • add work-item label
  • add informal rule that work-items can only be created by maintainers, and that they need to be separate from reports. Ie, we actively don't try to formulate "steps to fix" in the original report and instead file a separate work-item there.
  • remove actionable/unactionable label, as I think they are getting at the same thing, just from a wrong direction.

add informal rule that work-items can only be created by maintainers, and that they need to be separate from reports. Ie, we actively don't try to formulate "steps to fix" in the original report and instead file a separate work-item there.

I would say that many feature requests can actually directly be work items, so I wouldn't go as far as saying that they can only be created by maintainers (maintainers can also mark issues as work items)

Thinking about this again, how about just adding a C-support in addition to the existing C-bug and C-feature, to mark the various "help, things are not working" tickets? I think C-bug and C-feature basically cover the work-item concept, if we keep an eye on their quality and don't hesitate to create new issues if the original report is not clear enough
We could also enable Discussions, but I haven't used them much and I'm not sure how well they work for some of these issues.

well, we also say

For usage and troubleshooting requests, please use "IDEs and Editors" category of the Rust forum:

so I have some doubts that enabling discussions would lead to fewer support requests in the issues?
I mean, I guess we could point to it in the issue template. But probably it's fine to use issues for support, we should just have a way of sorting them out
You can convert an issue to a discussion

Community members can ask and answer questions, share updates, have open-ended conversations, and follow along on decisions affecting the community's way of working.

Support isn't open-ended, though. It feels like they're more for "discussions" rather than "Q&A"
yeah, I haven't used github discussions almost at all
so then maybe just keeping them as issues and marking them would be the right way after all?
https://youtu.be/IpBw2SJkFyk looks nice, though
